title: erdos313Solutions
content: The set of pairs (m, P) where m ≥ 2, P is a nonempty finset of distinct primes, and ∑ 1/p = 1 − 1/m.

title: Primary Pseudoperfect Number
content: An integer n is primary pseudoperfect if there exists a prime set P such that (n, P) is in the solution set. Only 8 such numbers are known.

title: Infinitude Conjecture
content: Are there infinitely many solutions? Equivalently, are there infinitely many primary pseudoperfect numbers? This is the main open question.

title: Example: m = 6
content: 1/2 + 1/3 = 5/6 = 1 − 1/6. The prime set is {2, 3} and the product is 6.

title: Product Constraint
content: In any solution (m, P), we must have m = p₁ · p₂ · ··· · pₖ. This means the prime factorization of m consists exactly of the primes in P.

title: Uniqueness
content: At most one prime set P works for each m, since P is determined by m's prime factorization.

title: At Least 8 Known
content: There are at least 8 known primary pseudoperfect numbers. The sequence grows explosively: 2, 6, 42, 1806, 47058, 2214502422, ...

title: Egyptian Fraction Form
content: The equation ∑ 1/pᵢ + 1/m = 1 is an Egyptian fraction representation of 1 with distinct denominators, all but one being prime.
